title: Generally in a Ch.7 bankruptcy, what is the norm to have left over on Schedule J?
question: I have about $1000 left over on my Schedule J budget. Is that okay? Or should I try to drop it down more? What are some "other expenses" that I can list?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Debt relief,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Felony crime,Fraud,Fees
answers: If there is a great disparity between your income after tax and other mandatory deductions and your expenses, the chapter 7 trustee will take the position that you are hiding income. In general, your expenses should be close to your income say by $200 to $500 margin. If there is substantial difference, you have to explain in either your schedule I or J that your expenses will reduce going forward or that your income will reduce going forward. Good luck

In Michigan, if you have more than $150.00 left over at the end of the month, you can expect an objection to you receiving a chapter 7 discharge.

A person wiser than me once said "anyone who represents themselves has a fool for a lawyer". Bankruptcy fraud is a felony. Worse yet, you will pay the Attorney fees of the other side if you make them prove that you are committing a fraud. We are talking about TENS of thousands of dollars in non dischargeable debt.

You NEED to talk to a Bankruptcy Attorney

My experience is in most cases, people forget many expenses that they have, but don't necessarily pay on a monthly basis. I.e., if you have petsdid you include pet expenses, such as vet bills, licenses, food, groomers, etc.; is your vehicle older, if so, check on your auto repair expenses, registrations, smog checks, etc.

I recommend to my clients that they go over their last year's cancelled checks and/or bank statements to get an accurate picture of what they actually spend on on-going expenses in order to jog their memories about things that go beyond the usual mortgage, utility and grocery bills.

Invariably, they discover expenses they forgot about and we then include those in their schedules. Just make sure that if you include an expense, its valid and supportable. After you have accounted for all the usual expenses and those that you have to pay irregularly throughout the year, you will have a better picture as to whether or not you have excess disposable income such that you may not qualify for a Chapter 7.

I

Not to be too ascerbic, and in addition to agreeing with the prior responses, but if you have surplus income of $1,000 per month, perhaps you should consider hiring a bankruptcy attorney who could more thoroughly analyze your budget and assist in presenting it properly to the court.

First of all, Sch J should list the expenses you actually have. The tenor of your question implies you're going to fudge something -- don't. Most of my Chapter 7 clients have I-minus-J of negative several hundred dollars (or more). With even a couple hundred dollars of disposable income, the powers that be where I practice would be pushing the debtor into Chapter 13.

Depends on the amount of debt you have. If you take the amount left over & multiply it by 60, is that amount at least 25% of your total debt? If so, expect the UST to object to you filing Chapter 7.

Hope this perspective helps!
